title: 112_s3558
content: The Act may be cited as the "Clean Water Cooperative Federalism Act of 2011" and pertains to state water quality standards. The "Clean Water Cooperative Federalism Act of 2011" amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act regarding State Water Quality Standards. It specifies conditions under which the Administrator may not promulgate a revised or new standard for a pollutant if the State has an approved standard, unless the State agrees with the Administrator's determination. The "Clean Water Cooperative Federalism Act of 2011" amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to limit the Administrator's authority in promulgating new standards if a State has an approved standard. It also restricts the Administrator from withdrawing approval of State programs under certain conditions. The "Clean Water Cooperative Federalism Act of 2011" limits the Administrator's authority to object to State water quality standards or Federal guidance interpretation. The Act also restricts the Administrator from withdrawing approval of State programs under specific conditions. The "Clean Water Cooperative Federalism Act of 2011" restricts the Administrator's authority to object to State water quality standards or Federal guidance interpretation. The "Clean Water Cooperative Federalism Act of 2011" limits the EPA Administrator's authority over permits for dredged or fill material under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. States must concur with the Administrator's determination for permits, and states can administer their own permit programs for some or all discharges. SEC. 4. DEADLINES FOR AGENCY COMMENTS. Amends Section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to require the Administrator and agency heads to submit comments on permit applications within 30 days (or 60 days with a request for additional time). SEC. 5. APPLICABILITY OF AMENDMENTS. SEC. 5. APPLICABILITY OF AMENDMENTS. The amendments made by this Act apply to actions taken on or after the enactment date, including permit applications and new standards. SEC. 6. REPORTING ON HARMFUL POLLUTANTS. The EPA Administrator must report to Congress annually on changes in waterborne pathogens, toxic chemicals, and metals in regulated waters. SEC. 7. PIPELINES CROSSING STREAMBEDS. SEC. 7. PIPELINES CROSSING STREAMBEDS. The Act does not limit the EPA's authority to regulate pipelines crossing streambeds. SEC. 8. IMPACTS OF EPA REGULATORY ACTIVITY ON EMPLOYMENT AND ECONOMIC ACTIVITY. Before taking a covered action, the Administrator must analyze the impact on employment levels and economic activity, including job losses and decreased economic activity by State. The Administrator will use the best available economic models for this analysis, and the Comptroller General will submit an annual report to Congress on the economic models used. The Administrator must post analysis of covered actions on the EPA website and request Governors to post it in their State if there is a negative impact. Public hearings are required in States with significant negative impacts on employment or economic activity at least 30 days before the action takes effect. The Administrator must hold public hearings at convenient times and locations for impacted residents, prioritizing areas with the highest job losses. If a covered action will significantly impact employment or economic activity in a State, notice must be given to the State's Congressional delegation, Governor, and Legislature at least 45 days before the action takes effect. The term "Administrator" refers to the head of the EPA. A "covered action" includes issuing regulations or implementing new programs under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act.
